conclusion: Understanding the relationship between magnetic force and magnetic field.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by the equation F = (μ₀IL)/(2πr).
μ₀ is the permeability of free space, approximately 4π × 10^-7 T·m/A.
I is the current in the wire.
L is the length of the wire.
r is the radius of the wire.
Given r = 0.5 m (radius of the wire frame) and I = 1 A (current in the wire frame).
Find the length L of the wire frame using the formula for the circumference of a circle: L = 2πr.
Substitute the given values to find L: L = 2π × 0.5 m = π m.
Calculate the magnetic force F on the entire wire frame using the formula F = (μ₀IL)/(2πr).
Substitute the values into the formula: F = (4π × 10^-7 T·m/A)(1 A)(π m)/(2π × 0.5 m).
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is 8 × 10^-7 T·m/A.
